Poll: Clinton beats Paul - and everybody else

Latest Bloomberg poll on 2016 gives Hillary Clinton the edge over Rand Paul and other would-be GOP presidential hopefuls

Poll: Clinton beats Paul - and everybody else

Politics

James R. Carroll, The Courier-Journal 7:09 a.m. EST December 9, 2014

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) said Dec. 3, 2014 that he will make up his mind on a 2016 White House presidential run in “the March/April time-frame.”

Buy Photo

Former First Lady and Secretary of State, Hillary Rodham Clinton, speaks during a rally for Senate candidate Alison Lundergan Grimes at Transylvania University in Lexington, Ky. Saturday, November 1, 2014. (Photo: Mike Weaver, Special to the C-J)Buy Photo

Tags

  • Ted Cruz
  • Rand Paul
  • Mitt Romney
  • Republican Party
  • Hillary Clinton
  • Chris Christie
  • Jeb Bush
76 CONNECT 9 TWEETLINKEDIN 25 COMMENTEMAILMORE

WASHINGTON - Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is still the one to beat in 2016.

That's the bottom line in a new Bloomberg Politics Poll on the presidential race, conducted by Des Moines-based Selzer & Co.

Clinton, the Democratic front-runner even though she has not yet announced her candidacy, would defeat any of the potential leading Republican candidates for president, including Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul. He, too, has not yet announced.

Among likely voters, Clinton leads Paul 47 percent to 37 percent, according to the survey.

In a match-up between Clinton and former GOP standard-bearer Mitt Romney, Clinton is ahead 45 percent to 39 percent.

A head-to-head race with former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush finds the former first lady up 43 percent to 37 percent.

Clinton bests New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie by a 42 percent to 36 percent margin, and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz by a 46 percent to 33 percent gap.

RELATED: Jennifer Lawrence slays Paul, McConnell in TIME poll

RELATED: Tops on Twitter: Clinton, Cruz, Paul

RELATED: Paul seeks re-election to the Senate, mum on presidential bid

The poll also asked voters to compare Clinton and potential GOP opponents.

"Who do you think is better at sharing your values?" the survey asked. When it was Clinton vs. Paul, voters chose Clinton, 49 percent to 36 percent.

"Who do you think is better at being a strong leader?" Clinton: 52 percent. Paul: 34 percent.

"Who do you think is better at caring about people like you?" Clinton: 48 percent. Paul: 37 percent.

"Who do you think is better at having a vision for the future?" Clinton: 48 percent. Paul: 38 percent.

Those numbers for Paul are generally a bit lower than those for Clinton vs. Romney, about the same range for Clinton vs. Bush and Clinton vs. Christie, and higher than those for Clinton vs. Cruz.

On the one-on-one match-ups, the poll surveyed 753 likely 2016 voters between Dec. 3 and 5. The poll has a margin or error of plus or minus 3.6 percentage points.
